title: $100 vs $1200 Headphones - 7hz x Crinacle Salnotes Dioko & Audeze Euclid Review
description: Check out Thorum using the link below and get 20% off by using the code LTT at checkout:    Airpods are expensive and will only last you a few years. Well, that's true of all wireless earbuds. So why do we keep buying them? Convenience probably. But when you are spending tons of money on something, you want it to last right? Well that's a big reason why WIRED headphones are making a comeback. We take a look at some entry-level planar magnetic earbuds, the 7hz x Crinacle Salnotes Dioko and compare them against the flagship Audeze Euclids. Just how good can $100 dollar headphones be? This isn't the first time we've covered planar magnetic driver technology on this channel, but it's likely the smallest. Now, hold on, Linus, you keep saying those words, "planar magnetic," but what do they mean? Let me explain. Most headphones, well, really, most audio products at all, use dynamic drivers. A dynamic driver consists of a coil of wire, that is attached to a flexible diaphragm. Typically a cone, like in this woofer, or a dome, like this tweeter. (words tweet) The coil is surrounded by magnets, and is suspended in the magnetic field. When an electrical signal is applied to the coil, it moves back and forth, translating its vibrations to the diaphragm, which then moves the air around it, creating sound Planer magnetic drivers, on the other hand, use a flat diaphragm, made of lightweight plastic, typically, with thin conductive wire, etched along the surface. The diaphragm is positioned between two magnets, on either side of the driver, and these magnets move the entire diaphragm at once. Why is this beneficial? Well, in a nutshell, it offers more precise control over the diaphragms movement, reducing distortion, and contributing to the planer magnetic driver's unique sound signature, which is often described as "clean" and "punchy." Planer magnetic drivers also tend to be larger, contributing to superior base response. Does this make planer magnetic headphones automatically better? Not really. Dynamic drivers benefit from a 50 year head start over planer magnetics. So, a lot of engineering and manufacturing expertise has gone into overcoming their weaknesses. Plus, compared to planer magnetics, they're more compact, and they require less power to operate. There's always trade-offs, right? But, anyway, we're not talking about headphones today. We're talking about earphones. Thanks to some recent manufacturing advances, great sounding planer magnetics, can be so small now, that they will fit inside your ear canals. And, over the past couple of years, an explosion of planer magnetic, in-ear monitors, or IEMs, has flooded the market. How does an explosion flood anything? How great do they sound? Well, $1,200 great. According to Audeze, one of the best known innovators in the planer magnetic space. In the base regions, both headphones look largely the same, meaning that you can expect a similar intensity in the base notes that you hear, rather than the ones that you feel. Then making our way into the upper-mids, our specimens start to diverge again. The Diokos have more presence in the mids, with some peaks near 2 and 3000 hertz, which could make them sound shouty, but could also accentuate upper female vocals. Then there's these peaks at 8,000 hertz, and 10,000 hertz, that could be caused for concern, especially if you're sensitive to sibilance. It means, sounds like "S" and "T" in speech, could be loud, and instruments like symbols, and crunchy distortion on guitars, could come across as sharp or fatiguing. The Euclids, meanwhile, offer a much milder treble experience. That, to my ears, sounds great. I mean, there is no question that these are audiophile grade. As for the dipped low-mids, they made even fine male vocalists sound a little boring. The rest of the treble region, though, was detailed and quite delightful.
